info.para: An example of finding a basis for the row space of a matrix
An example of finding a basis for the column space of a matrix

statement.para: For an (m,n)-matrix \Mtrx{A} with row reduced echelon form \Mtrx{B} the following hold:

part.para: A basis for the row space V of \Mtrx{A} is given by the nonzero rows of \Mtrx{B}; therefore \Dim{ V }=\Rnk{ \Mtrx{A} }.
A basis for the column space W of \Mtrx{A} is given by selecting from \Mtrx{A} the column vectors in those positions in which \Mtrx{B} has a leading 1. Therefore, \Dim{ W }=\Rnk{ \Mtrx{A} }.

proof.caption: BasisRowSpace Finding a basis for the row space of \Mtrx{A}
proof.para: The argument consists of two parts. In the first part we show that \Mtrx{A} and \Mtrx{B} have the same row space. This is accomplished by showing that a row operation leaves the row space unchanged. In the second part of the argument we show that the nonzero row vectors of \Mtrx{B} are linearly independent. â€“ Here are the details.
\Mtrx{A} and \Mtrx{B} have the same row space We show that each of the three types of row operations used to reduce a matrix to RREF leaves its row space unchanged.

proof.para: Proof that the nonzero rows of a matrix in reduced row echelon form are linearly independent We need to recall that a matrix in RREF has the following appearance.

From the nonzero rows, select the columns containing a leading 1. The resulting matrix is the identity matrix of size (r,r), where r denotes the rank. Its determinant is 1\neq 0. Therefore the nonzero row vectors are linearly independent. The 0-row vectors don't contribute to the row span. So the nonzero row vectors of \Mtrx{B} form a basis for the row space of \Mtrx{A}.

These column vectors are linearly independent and span the column space of \Mtrx{B}. Therefore they form a basis for the column space of \Mtrx{B}. Let \EuScript{B}:= \Set{ C_1,\dots ,C_r } be the set of column vectors of \Mtrx{A} taken from those positions in which \Mtrx{B} has a leading 1. While, in general, the column space of \Mtrx{A} is different from the column space of \Mtrx{B}, we will see that the column vectors of both matrices satisfy the same linear dependency relations and, as a consequence, that \EuScript{B} is a basis of \ColSp{\Mtrx{A} }. We begin by expressing \Mtrx{A} and \Mtrx{B} in terms of their column vectors.

Suppose A_j is not in \span\Set{ C_1,\dots ,C_r}. Then the set \Set{ A_j,C_1,\dots ,C_r} is linearly independent. On the other hand, the j-th column of \Mtrx{B} can be written as

proof.para: But this contradicts the assumption that \Set{ A_j,C_1,\dots ,C_r} is linearly independent. Thus A_j\in \ColSp{ \EuScript{B} }, which completes the proof that \EuScript{B} is a basis of \ColSp{ \Mtrx{A} }. The proof of the proposition is complete.
